screening_results.reason: fMRI study directly investigates perception of eye gaze and face identity — social communication and perception of others — in human participants. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract does not specify participant ages or explicitly state 'healthy' but likely healthy adults; include for full-text review to confirm sample characteristics and age range.

fMRI study in healthy adult participants (self-identified White and Black) performing a social perception task (viewing in-group vs out-group faces). This addresses social-related processing (perception/understanding of others) and is not a review; abstract provides sufficient info.

fMRI study examining processing of gaze direction—a clearly social cue—reporting fusiform and connectivity effects. Appears to use healthy human participants and is not a review. Abstract does not report participant ages/health in detail, so include for full-text to confirm eligibility.

Functional MRI was used while participants made empathic and forgivability judgments—clearly social-related tasks (perception/understanding of others). Event-related fMRI study where participants judged trustworthiness of faces — a social cognition task (perception/understanding of others). Not a review. Abstract does not state participant ages or health status; therefore include for full-text review to confirm healthy adult sample and ages (17–65).

Abstract describes simultaneous fMRI (hyperscanning) during an interactive social task (a deception game) with human participants. fMRI study of causal attributions (self-responsibility, self-serving bias) during attributional decision tasks — a social cognition task involving perception/understanding of self. Primary fMRI study examining mutual vs. averted social gaze (social perception/communication). Not a review. Abstract does not specify participant ages or explicit confirmation of healthy adult sample, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

fMRI study examining social interaction (cooperation vs competition) with participants interacting with another person; this directly addresses social processing in humans. Abstract implies healthy adult sample though age not specified—sufficient to include for full-text confirmation.

Age range not specified but sample described as participants (likely adults); sufficient evidence from abstract to include for full-text data extraction.

Functional MRI was used while 19 healthy adult participants viewed social audiovisual movie clips (social perception task). Study directly investigates social processing in healthy adults and is not a review or meta-analysis.

The fMRI tasks probe working memory and incidental episodic encoding (memory processes), not social-related processing (e.g., affiliation, social communication, self/other perception). Therefore it does not meet the review’s requirement for social-related tasks in healthy adults.

fMRI study investigating affiliative emotion (a social-related construct) in humans. Abstract implies healthy adult participants though ages not specified; meets primary inclusion criteria for social-processing fMRI. Insufficient age details—include for full-text review to confirm participant ages and health status.

fMRI was conducted while healthy adult mothers listened to their own and unfamiliar infant cries — a social/attachment-related task (Affiliation/Attachment). Participants are adults (mothers) within the eligible age range and no indication of clinical disorders; not a review. Meets inclusion criteria based on the abstract.

fMRI study of empathy and perspective-taking (self/other) in healthy human subjects performing social-related tasks (pain perception/empathy). Meets inclusion criteria for social processing in healthy adults.

fMRI study includes social cognition tasks (reasoning about others’ mental states) performed by neurologically normal participants; meets inclusion of social-related fMRI in healthy adults. Not a review/meta-analysis.

fMRI study of emotional facial expressions (social communication) in humans and monkeys, and reports human neural responses—directly relevant to social processing. Abstract does not specify participant ages or explicitly state healthy adult status, so inclusion for full-text review is warranted to confirm eligibility.

Participants are adolescents (not within the required adult age range 17–65), and the fMRI task used was the Monetary Incentive Delay task (monetary reward), which is not a social-related task; maternal affiliation was measured but neural data were collected during a non-social task.

fMRI study examining neural systems for social cognition (mirror neuron and mentalizing systems) during action observation—clearly a social-related task. Abstract does not state participant ages or explicitly 'healthy adults,' so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

fMRI study investigating selection between self and other visual perspectives — a social-cognitive process (perception/understanding of others). Study reports task-based fMRI in human participants (healthy adults implied), not a review or meta-analysis. Fits inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

fMRI was used to measure brain responses during action observation and execution after sensorimotor training; study investigates mirror-system responses relevant to perception/understanding of others (social processing). Participants are human adults (no clinical groups reported). Meets inclusion criteria for fMRI social-related processing in healthy adults.

Combined fMRI (with eye-tracking) study directly probes social interaction vs social observation, targeting perception/understanding of others. Appears to involve healthy adult participants and is an original empirical study (not a review). Meets inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social processing in healthy adults.

fMRI study manipulating social versus nonsocial information in an n-back task; reports activation in social cognition and face-processing regions, so addresses social-related processing. Abstract does not specify participant ages or health status, so include for full-text review to confirm at least one healthy adult group (age 17–65).

fMRI study with healthy adult participants performing a social-related task (perception of others' pain/suffering). Results report neural responses to others’ suffering and modulation by mortality salience; not a review/meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria (social processing, healthy adults). Age not specified beyond ‘adults’ but likely within 17–65; abstract provides sufficient information for inclusion.

Abstract explicitly reports a meta-analysis component. Exclusion criteria disallow systematic reviews or meta-analyses. Although an empirical fMRI study is also reported, the presence of a meta-analysis meets the exclusion criterion.

Event-related fMRI study probing gender perception from faces (perception/understanding of others), a social processing task. Appears to involve healthy adult participants and is an original empirical study (not a review). Abstract provides sufficient evidence to include for full-text data extraction.

Event-related fMRI study in healthy adult participants performing a social task (interpersonal resource conflict and sharing); reports neural responses related to social appraisal/decision-making. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study with healthy adult participants investigating abstract vs. concrete mindsets within social cognition context. Abstract does not clearly state socially-specific tasks or stimuli, so insufficient information to rule out relevance; include for full-text review to confirm social-related processing.

fMRI study where participants made attractiveness (beauty) comparisons—this is social processing (perception/understanding of others). Human participants implied to be healthy adults; no exclusion criteria met. Thus meets inclusion for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

Study uses functional MRI during a social interaction (cyber-ball) task examining neural responses to social inclusion/exclusion and face perception; participants appear to be healthy adults and the paper addresses social processing in the brain, meeting the review’s inclusion criteria.

Abstract reports fMRI experiments in which participants performed mentalizing (social-cognitive) tasks about individuals and groups. It is empirical (not a review) and examines social processing in human participants. Although participant ages/health status are not specified in the abstract, the study should be included for full-text review to confirm inclusion criteria (healthy adults 17–65).

Empirical fMRI study using a social task (speed-dating) examining responses to romantic interest/rejection—fits social processing constructs (affiliation, perception of others). Involves healthy adult participants and is not a review. Abstract provides sufficient information to include for full-text extraction.

fMRI study examining communicative intentions (social communication), matching review topic. Abstract does not report participant health status or ages (17–65), so include for full-text review to confirm sample characteristics.

fMRI study with healthy adult participants (mean age 24) performing a social-related task (handholding with friend/stranger vs alone during threat). Fits inclusion criteria for social processing in healthy adults; not a review.

fMRI study examining perception and social-communicative processing of different laughter types—fits social communication/perception constructs. Abstract does not specify participant health status or ages (17–65), so include for full-text review to confirm healthy adult sample and age range.

fMRI study of social communicative gesture observation and imitation in twenty adult participants. Directly investigates social communication/perception and reports neural activations; participants are described as healthy adults (no disorders mentioned) and age likely within 17–65. Not a review. Meets inclusion criteria.

Abstract reports altered neural activation and connectivity associated with compassion training and altruistic behavior in healthy adults, indicating neuroimaging of social-related processing. Although it does not explicitly state 'fMRI' or task details, the neural activation/connectivity findings imply functional imaging during social-emotional tasks; include for full-text review to confirm imaging modality and task specifics.

fMRI study with healthy participants (N=31) performing a social-related gambling task comparing self, friend, and antagonist, probing perception/understanding of others and reward-related social processing. Abstract does not report participant ages; include for full-text review to confirm age range falls within 17–65.

fMRI was used while participants encoded messages they later communicated — a social-communication/social-influence task involving mentalizing and reward systems. Study appears to involve healthy adult participants and is an original fMRI study (not a review). Abstract provides sufficient information to include for the review.

fMRI study in healthy participants assessing recognition of others’ action dynamics ('vitality form'), a social-perception task (perception/understanding of others). Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract clearly meets inclusion criteria.

fMRI study with 46 healthy volunteers performing theory-of-mind tasks about emotions, beliefs, and pain—clearly a social-related task (perception/understanding of others). Participants are human adults; not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to include for full-text data extraction.

Study used functional MRI during a social-evaluation task (believed being watched by a peer), reports neural responses including MPFC engagement, and includes an adult participant group (adolescents and adults). Participants are human and presumably healthy; not a review. Thus meets inclusion criteria for fMRI social-processing in healthy adults.

fMRI study where healthy adult participants (21 males) performed a social-related task (perception/understanding of dyadic nonverbal behavior). Meets inclusion criteria and no exclusion criteria apparent from abstract.

fMRI study with healthy participants performing an impression-formation task (social perception/understanding of others). Reports neural (dorsomedial PFC) activity during a social task. Not a review/meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria.

fMRI study of social perception (biological motion) in humans; includes adult participants and reports adult results (healthy adults implied). Task assesses social perception, fitting the review objective. Not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient info to include for full-text data extraction.

fMRI study in healthy adult participants using social-related tasks (eye-gaze detection, self-propelling motion, and implicit mental inference). Fits inclusion criteria (social processing, healthy adults 17–65). Not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to include for full-text data extraction.

fMRI was used during a social task (third-party punishment, attribution of others’ intentions), and participants are described as lay people (presumably healthy adults). Age range not specified in abstract; insufficient to confirm ages, so include for full-text review.

fMRI study assessing socio-cognitive processing (viewing social driving videos) comparing groups of drivers; involves healthy adult participants and directly examines social cognition. Not a review. Abstract meets inclusion criteria.

Abstract is described as a review and lacks participant, task, and sample health/age details. It mentions human fMRI findings but does not provide enough information to confirm primary fMRI data in healthy adults. Insufficient information to determine eligibility, so include for full-text review.

fMRI study using face stimuli (social perception) with a continuous sample from childhood through adulthood; adult participants are included (adulthood) and task probes social-related face processing. No exclusion criteria met. Full text may be checked to confirm exact adult age range (17–65).

fMRI was used while participants evaluated personal attributes (a social-cognitive task: perception/understanding of self/others). No indication of clinical populations; likely healthy adults. Meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in adults. Age range not specified, so moderate-high confidence (0.90) to include for full-text review.

Non-human animal study: fMRI and behavioral framework discussed for songbirds, not human participants. Does not involve healthy adult humans (age 17–65) performing a social-related task; therefore it does not meet inclusion criteria.

Abstract/title indicates brain responses during evaluation of face approachability (a social task). However the abstract does not explicitly state use of fMRI or participant ages/health. Insufficient information to confirm imaging modality and sample details, so include for full-text review to verify fMRI and healthy adult sample.

Study reports functional MRI experiments in healthy adult participants using a social/empathy task (visuo-tactile paradigm assessing emotional egocentricity bias) and identifies task-related activations. It is an original empirical fMRI study of social cognition, not a review, meeting inclusion criteria.

Event-related fMRI paradigm directly examines processing of social vs nonsocial gestures (social cognition). Abstract does not state participant health status or ages; likely healthy adults but insufficient detail. Include for full-text review to confirm participants meet healthy adult (17–65) criterion.

fMRI study with human participants performing collaborative vs. competitive tasks (social contexts). Investigates social motivation and social-cognition brain regions (TPJ, reward circuits). Meets inclusion criteria (social-related task, healthy adults likely; not a review).

Abstract reports an fMRI study where participants received tactile stimulation and judged ambiguous social interactions (social perception/understanding). Neural activations (somatosensory cortices, amygdala, hippocampus, prefrontal cortex) are reported. Participants appear to be healthy adults. No exclusion criteria met.

Abstract reports functional MRI (fMRI) responses to guilt in healthy individuals performing a task probing moral sentiments (social processing). Although the primary analysis focused on structural VBM, fMRI data related to social/moral emotions are explicitly described, meeting inclusion criteria.

Study used simultaneous fMRI during live verbal interaction (social communication) in healthy adult participants (11 pairs of female friends). Directly assesses social-related processing with functional imaging and is not a review, meeting inclusion criteria.

fMRI study with 44 healthy participants performing explicit social trait judgments (trustworthiness, attractiveness) using voice stimuli, directly addressing social processing in healthy adults. No exclusion criteria met. Include for full-text review to confirm participant ages and additional details.

fMRI study presenting video clips assessing empathy and social communication; participants performed a social-related task. Reports BOLD responses and connectivity in modality-related regions; not a review. Participants appear to be healthy adults. Fits inclusion criteria for social-processing fMRI in healthy adults.

Abstract reports an fMRI study of social-cognitive processes (empathy, Theory of Mind, self–other differentiation) in human participants, matching the review objective. The abstract does not specify participant ages or explicitly state health status; therefore inclusion for full-text review is warranted to confirm that at least one group are healthy adults (17–65).

Abstract reports event-related fMRI during one-shot, anonymous prisoner's dilemma—a social cognition task (cooperation/understanding others) with neural activations in mPFC, TPJ, precuneus. It is an original fMRI study (not a review). Participant health status and ages are not specified in the abstract; likely healthy adults but need full text to confirm demographics. Include for full-text review to verify sample meets age/health criteria.

Abstract reports the author’s fMRI studies examining social emotions (guilt, embarrassment, pride, envy) in humans and discusses social neuroscience and decision-making, indicating relevant fMRI social-task data. It does not specify participant health status or ages, nor methodological details. Not clearly a systematic review/meta-analysis. Insufficient information to confirm healthy adult sample and task specifics, so include for full-text review to determine eligibility.

This study used rhesus monkeys (non-human primates) with single-unit recordings and fMRI-defined patches, not fMRI in human participants performing social-related tasks. It does not involve healthy adult humans (age 17–65) or a human social-processing task, so it does not meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study comparing neural responses to familiar vs. unfamiliar faces (social perception/understanding of others). Includes an age-matched control group of healthy adults. Although centered on a patient with Capgras, the presence of healthy participants and a social-related task meets inclusion criteria.

fMRI study using the ultimatum game examining social decision-making networks, which matches the review objective (social processing). Abstract does not specify participant ages or whether a healthy adult group (17–65) was included. Insufficient information to confirm age criteria—include for full-text review to determine eligibility.

fMRI study reporting brain activity during live social exchanges (reciprocal imitation), addressing social cognition (Mirror and Mentalizing systems). Appears to involve human participants performing a social-related task; not a review. No indication of clinical populations; meets inclusion criteria for healthy adult fMRI social processing studies.

fMRI study in healthy adults examining brain responses to interpersonal manual touch (holding, smoothing, poking). Interpersonal touch is a social stimulus relevant to social interaction/affiliation, meeting the review’s inclusion criteria. Not a review/meta-analysis.

Abstract reports examination of neural substrates of social cognition and face processing in healthy young adults, matching the review topic and population. However, it does not specify that an fMRI task was used or provide task details; include for full-text review to confirm imaging modality and task.

Human fMRI study investigating social distance (photographs of participants' friends vs acquaintances) alongside spatial/temporal distance. Involves social-related processing (social familiarity/affiliation) in likely healthy adult participants. Not a review article. Abstract provides sufficient info to include for full-text data extraction.

Abstract reports task-based functional MRI during a social closeness task (photos of friends vs unknown people), clearly addressing social processing in human participants. Participant health and exact ages aren’t specified in the abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm adult (17–65) healthy sample.

fMRI study examining social-related processes (direct and reflected self- and other-evaluations). Includes a healthy young adult group aged 22–31 (within 17–65). Not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient info to meet inclusion criteria.

Abstract reports an fMRI study of social influence (bystander effect) while participants witnessed an emergency—this is a social-related task probing perception/understanding of others and action preparation. It describes human participants scanned with fMRI. The abstract does not specify participant ages/health explicitly, so include for full-text review to confirm they are healthy adults (17–65).
Participants are non-human (dogs). Meta-analysis requires fMRI studies of healthy human adults (age 17–65); this study does not meet participant criteria.

fMRI study of social cognitive processing (attribution to self/other/situation) in a typical (healthy) adult sample. Task assesses social perception/understanding of others/self. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to include for full-text data extraction.

The study reports an fMRI experiment where participants attributed states of awareness to a cartoon face (social attribution/perception of others). Participants appear to be healthy adults and this is primary research (not a review). Thus it meets the fMRI social-processing inclusion criteria.

fMRI study examining neural correlates of social exclusion (Cyberball) and responses (punishment/forgiveness) during a social decision task (modified Dictator Game). Involves human participants and social cognitive processes; not a review. Abstract sufficiently indicates relevance to social-related processing in healthy adults; include for full-text extraction.

fMRI study investigating anticipatory sensorimotor processes during active interpersonal touch versus inanimate touch — a social-related task involving perception/understanding of others. Appears to involve human participants and is an original fMRI study (not a review). The abstract does not specify participant ages, so full text should be checked, but inclusion is warranted for full-text review.

fMRI study examining self- and other-referential recollection (social cognition: perception/understanding of self and others). Not a review. Abstract does not report participant ages/health explicitly, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

Abstract reports an fMRI experiment in healthy adult participants assessing self-referential processing during intergroup competition (a social cognitive task) and links neural responses to willingness to harm competitors. This clearly meets the review’s inclusion criteria (fMRI, social-related processing, healthy participants). Not a review or meta-analysis.

fMRI study in healthy human participants (n=25) measuring responses to faces; facial color processing relates to social communication/perception of others, fitting the review’s social-related processing objective. Abstract lacks explicit ages but otherwise meets inclusion.

Abstract reports fMRI data collected in Berlin during a face-to-face social feedback task where healthy German and Chinese adult participants updated self- and other-trait ratings. This directly addresses social processing (self/other understanding) in healthy adults and is not a review. Meets inclusion criteria.

fMRI study investigating social influence/emotion alignment during a social interaction task; reports neural activity in healthy participants. Meets inclusion (social-related task, fMRI, human participants). No exclusion criteria met. Age not specified in abstract, so full text should be checked, but abstract provides sufficient basis to include for full-text review.

fMRI study with a non-clinical sample of 20 young adult male participants performing empathy-related social-interaction tasks (viewing first-person social scenarios). Targets social perception/understanding in healthy adults (age within 17–65) and is not a review.

fMRI study examining perception/understanding of others’ social interactions (third-person perspective), meeting the social-related task criterion. Abstract does not specify participant ages or explicitly state healthy sample; insufficient to exclude. Include for full-text review to confirm participant details and eligibility.

3T fMRI study where participants (presumably healthy adults) performed a social-related task (imagining triadic interactions). Reports neural activity in mentalizing and mirror systems. Not a review/meta-analysis and fits inclusion criteria for fMRI social processing in healthy adults.

fMRI study using an ultimatum game probing fairness (social decision-making/perception of others), meeting the social-task requirement. Abstract does not specify participant ages or health status, so inclusion cannot be confirmed solely from abstract; include for full-text review to verify healthy adult sample (17–65).

Study used fMRI during a social interaction task (Taylor Aggression Paradigm) presenting angry/neutral facial expressions and examined neural responses in healthy participants. Fits review objective (social processing in healthy adults). Age range not specified in abstract; include for full-text to confirm ages and other details.

fMRI was conducted while healthy adult participants (N=16) performed a social interaction task (matching-pennies) involving human and non-human agents. The study examines perception and understanding of others (social cognition), matching the review objective. Not a review or meta-analysis.

Primary data fMRI study of impression formation (social evaluation of others) in humans. Task is social-cognitive (person evaluation), uses functional MRI, and implies healthy adult participants. Not a review/meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria.

fMRI was used while participants performed an implicit false-belief (theory-of-mind) social task, directly addressing social processing. Abstract does not specify participant ages or explicitly state healthy adults, so inclusion for full-text review is warranted to confirm eligibility.

Abstract reports a task-based neuroimaging study of interpersonal synchrony and social affiliation in human participants (n=100). The study examines social-cognitive processes and reports brain-area involvement, consistent with functional neuroimaging during a social task in healthy adults. Although the abstract does not explicitly state “fMRI” or participant ages, it clearly addresses social processing and warrants full-text review to confirm imaging modality and age range.

fMRI study with 20 healthy adult male volunteers viewing campaign videos designed to elicit empathy—a social cognitive process (understanding others). Meets inclusion: task-based fMRI, social-related processing, healthy participants (adults). Not a review/meta-analysis.

fMRI study in humans examining cross-modal recognition of others (voice-face identity), which is social perception of others. Uses healthy human participants (adults implied). Meets criteria of social-related task and fMRI; no exclusion criteria met.

Resting-state (task-free) fMRI study focusing on ATL connectivity with the language network; no social-related task was performed. Although ATL is linked to social cognition in general, the abstract reports no social processing task, so it does not meet the task-based inclusion criterion.

fMRI study in humans examining neural responses to biological (social) vs scrambled motion, addressing perception/decoding of social signals (Perception and Understanding of Others). Appears to involve healthy adult participants and meets the review’s inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

fMRI was used while healthy adult participants (N=50, young adults within 17–65) performed a social-related task (labeling brief emotional facial expressions — perception/understanding of others). Study is empirical neuroimaging, not a review, meeting inclusion criteria.
Participants were non-human (domestic dogs) undergoing fMRI; the review requires human participants age 17–65. Therefore the study does not meet the population inclusion criterion.

Empirical fMRI study in healthy adult participants examining social-affiliative processing (social sharing of emotions) during task performance; functional MRI was used and the sample comprises healthy friends. Not a review. Meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in adults.

fMRI study where participants processed social communication (text messages believed to be from a friend vs. a computer). Involves healthy adult participants (no clinical groups reported) and examines social-related processing (social communication, mental state processing). Not a review; meets inclusion criteria.

Original fMRI study using model-driven fMRI during a public good (social decision-making) task examining neural correlates of social tie formation and prosocial behavior in human participants. Meets inclusion: task is social-related, functional MRI used, healthy adult participants implied. Not a review/meta-analysis.

Abstract describes a social communication task with cerebral activity measured in healthy communicators but does not specify fMRI. Insufficient imaging-modality detail; include for full-text review to confirm fMRI and eligibility.

Abstract describes hyperscanning methods and a review/discussion of EEG, fMRI, fNIRS techniques rather than reporting an original fMRI experiment with healthy adults performing a social task. No participants, task, or fMRI results are reported; thus it does not meet inclusion criteria.
Animal (mouse) resting-state fMRI study; no human participants or task-based social processing. Does not meet inclusion criteria of fMRI in healthy adult humans performing social-related tasks.

fMRI study investigating neural correlates of initiating/responding to joint attention—a social communication task—in human participants. Abstract indicates experimental fMRI in an interactive social paradigm but does not specify participant ages/health; include for full-text review to confirm sample characteristics and eligibility.

Abstract reports fMRI during a dyadic social task (eye contact) and identifies neural networks for reciprocal social interaction, aligning with the review objective. However, participant health status and age range (17–65) are not specified in the abstract, so full-text review is needed to confirm sample eligibility.

fMRI study with 37 healthy adult participants performing a social-communication task (evaluating feeling of being addressed). Examines neural processing of social cues (gesture and body orientation). Not a review or meta-analysis, meets inclusion criteria.

fMRI study measuring neural responses while participants performed a social perception task (judging congruent vs. incongruent person dyads). Participants are healthy adults; study is empirical (not a review). Meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

fMRI study examining perception/understanding of others’ emotions in dynamic crowds (social perception task). Abstract does not specify participant ages or health status, so inclusion cannot be confirmed from abstract alone. Per guideline, include for full-text review to verify healthy adult (17–65) sample and other details.

fMRI study where participants made strategic decisions to lie or tell the truth in a game-theoretic social interaction, probing social cognition (deception, understanding others). Involves healthy adult participants (typical sample) and is not a review; meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

Participants are adolescents (ages 12–15), but the meta-analysis requires healthy adults aged 17–65. Although it uses fMRI and a social task, the sample falls outside the eligible age range, so exclude.

Study uses resting-state fMRI in children aged 3–5 and investigates developmental DMN connectivity; does not involve a social-related task nor include healthy adult participants (17–65). Does not meet inclusion criteria.
Participants are older adults (mean age 79), outside the review’s required age range (17–65). No group of healthy participants within 17–65 is reported, so the study does not meet inclusion criteria.

Original fMRI study with 18 adult participants performing a social-cognitive task (predicting others’ behavior; theory-of-mind and deontic inference). Involves social processing and healthy adult sample; not a review or meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria.

Abstract reports original dfMRI experimental results on reciprocal eye-contact (a social interaction) and analyses of BOLD responses; not a review. Participant characteristics (health status, age range) are not specified in the abstract, so full-text is needed to confirm inclusion criteria (healthy adults 17–65). Include for full-text review.

This is a theoretical/narrative paper discussing explanations for mirror-touch synesthesia; the abstract does not report conducting an fMRI study or list participants. It reviews fMRI evidence but is not an original fMRI experiment with healthy adult participants, so it does not meet the inclusion criteria.

Original fMRI study investigating attributional processes about others (social cognition) in humans. Uses functional MRI during a social-related task (attributing beliefs/motives) and reports findings in healthy adult participants. Not a review or meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social processing.

fMRI study investigating social-affective modulation of mimicry (affiliation, social perception) using facial stimuli—clearly a social-related task. Abstract does not specify participant ages or health status; therefore include for full-text review to confirm participants are healthy adults within 17–65.

Task-based fMRI study in young, healthy adults examining social reward processing (social vs monetary) using an incentive delay task. Fits review focus on social-related processing in healthy adults and is not a review or meta-analysis.

Human fMRI study examining social working memory and perspective-taking neural correlates; addresses social processing in healthy adults. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract clearly reports task-based fMRI of social cognitive processes, so meets inclusion criteria.

fMRI study investigating gaze following and social attention (perception/understanding of others) in human participants. Appears to use healthy adult participants and meets inclusion criteria; not a review or meta-analysis.

Empirical fMRI study of social perception/cognition in human participants (STS responses to social and linguistic stimuli). Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract does not specify participant ages, but it implies healthy adult participants; insufficient age detail warrants full-text review to confirm eligibility.

fMRI study where participants judged actions at different levels of abstraction, engaging mental-state reasoning and action-representation networks—fits social cognitive processing. Not a review. Abstract implies healthy adult participants; age not specified, but per instructions inclusion is appropriate for full-text review if uncertain.

fMRI study using gender identification of angry and happy faces (social-emotional processing) with N=30 participants. Abstract does not explicitly state participants’ health status or ages, so full text needed to confirm they are healthy adults (17–65). No exclusion criteria met.

Study reports fMRI in 164 healthy adult subjects performing an interactive social/mentalizing task (Prisoner’s Dilemma) assessing attachment-related social processing. Not a review/meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

fMRI study with healthy adult participants performing an imitation task related to social behavior (imitation underpinning language and social interaction). Directly examines social-related processing (urge to imitate and associated neural correlates). Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient info to include for full-text review.

fMRI task involved social-related processing (responses to parents; mentalizing/social cognition). Sample are healthy adolescents with mean age 17 (within the 17–65 inclusion range). Not a review. Abstract provides sufficient info to include for full-text review.

Participants are infants (4–7 months), not healthy adults aged 17–65; no adult participant group is reported. Although it investigates social-related voice processing, it does not meet the inclusion criterion of at least one healthy adult group.

Abstract reports a functional neuroimaging (fMRI) study in which participants viewed social scenes (a social cognition/mentalizing task) and linked dmPFC responses to daily social behavior; sample appears to be healthy adults. This matches inclusion criteria for fMRI of social-related processing in healthy adults. No exclusion criteria met.

fMRI study directly investigates social-reputation processing (a social-related task) in male and female participants, matching the review objective. Abstract does not specify participant ages or explicit health status; insufficient demographic detail to confirm inclusion criteria, so include for full-text review to verify age and health.

EmpaToM is an fMRI study manipulating empathy and Theory of Mind—social cognitive processes (Perception/Understanding of Others). Large samples (N=90, N=178) indicate healthy adult participants; not a review. Satisfies inclusion criteria for fMRI social processing in healthy adults.

fMRI study where healthy adult participants performed a gaze-following task probing social attention/perception of others, directly addressing social-related processing. No exclusion criteria met. Abstract does not state participant ages explicitly, so include for full-text review to confirm demographics and methodology.

The abstract addresses Theory of Mind (a social cognitive process) relevant to the review objective but does not specify whether an fMRI was conducted or report participant demographics/health status. Insufficient methodological detail in the abstract — include for full-text review to determine fMRI use and sample of healthy adults.

Abstract reports fMRI of negative emotion processing and sex differences in fronto-limbic connectivity in (presumably) healthy adults, but does not specify whether the task involved social-related stimuli or processes. Insufficient information to determine eligibility for a social-processing meta-analysis — include for full-text review.

fMRI was used while participants performed an empathy-for-pain task involving ingroup/outgroup (social processing: perception/understanding of others). Sample: 30 healthy adult participants. Not a review. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study of social perception (observers viewing violent social interactions; attention to aggressor vs victim) fits social-related processing. Abstract describes task and neural outcomes but does not explicitly state participant health status or ages; insufficient detail to confirm inclusion criteria, so include for full-text review.

Functional MRI was used while participants read passages varying in social content; the study examines social cognition/theory of mind and links dmPFC activity to social cognitive performance. Participants appear to be healthy adults. This fits the fMRI social-processing inclusion criteria and is not a review.

Study uses resting-state fMRI in macaque monkeys (non-human) and does not involve human participants performing a social-related task. Inclusion requires task-based fMRI in healthy adults (age 17–65).

Abstract reports an fMRI experiment examining self-referential and social stimulus processing in humans, matching the review objective. However, it does not state participant health status or ages (17–65). Include for full-text review to confirm healthy adult sample and eligibility.

fMRI study using the Cyberball social exclusion task (a social-related paradigm) in human participants; reports neural activity linked to social processing (emotion regulation) and behavioral measures (romantic relationship satisfaction). No indication this is a review or that participants are outside healthy adult range. Abstract provides sufficient info to include for full-text data extraction.

fMRI study examining disgust perception in racial prejudice during a passive face-viewing task—clearly social perception/understanding of others. Abstract implies healthy participants and does not mention clinical groups. Age range not specified, so full text should be checked, but abstract meets primary inclusion criteria; include for full-text review.

fMRI study investigating social cognition (agency and communion) using a valence classification task with reported neural activations; not a review. Abstract implies human participants performing a social-related task but does not specify ages/health. Include for full-text review to confirm participant age range and health status.

The abstract explicitly states the paper is a review of studies (not an original fMRI experiment). It focuses on development in children and ASD and does not report fMRI data collected in healthy adults (17–65). Thus it meets the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses.

fMRI study investigating social communication (understanding speech acts: Requests vs Naming) in human participants. Abstract implies healthy adult participants but does not report ages; content clearly matches review objective. Include for full-text review to confirm sample age range and health status.

Original fMRI hyperscanning study of mutual gaze and joint attention (social processing) in human participant pairs. It reports task-based fMRI neural synchronization related to shared attention; not a review. Meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

This fMRI study directly investigates social vs. nonsocial gesture processing and neural correlates, matching the review objective. The abstract does not explicitly state participant health status or exact ages, so inclusion requires full-text confirmation of a healthy adult sample (17–65). Include for full-text review to verify sample characteristics and eligibility.

fMRI study examining explicit control of interpersonal trust/distrust (social attitude processing) in a sample of healthy participants (n=60). The task is social-related (perception/attitudes toward others) and the study is primary research (not a review). Age range not stated in abstract, but inclusion criteria allow healthy adult groups; include for full-text review to confirm ages.

Empirical fMRI study in healthy adult social networks; participants viewed faces of others (social cognition task). Whole-brain fMRI collected during social-related processing (popularity, social valuation, mentalizing). Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study with 26 healthy adult participants performing an empathy-evoking social cognition task (film clips with contextual cues and music). Investigates empathic concern and neural connectivity during social processing. Meets inclusion criteria (functional MRI during social-related task in healthy adults) and is not a review.

fMRI study with healthy adult participants investigating social-interactive processing (mentalizing) during speech perception. Tasks directly probe social cognition/perception of others; matches inclusion criteria and no exclusion criteria met from abstract.

fMRI study employing MVPA during social cognition (‘thinking about others’ mental states’), directly addressing social processing. Abstract does not specify participant ages or clinical status; because inclusion requires at least one healthy adult group and this is unclear from the abstract, include for full-text review to confirm demographics and eligibility.

fMRI study with healthy participants (N=26) performing a social task (learning about others' generosity). Directly addresses social processing in healthy adults and is an original empirical study, not a review. Age range not specified in abstract, but participant group appears to be healthy adults; include for full-text review to confirm ages and details.

The abstract describes an original fMRI study using dyadic (live eye contact) social interaction—clearly a social-related task probing empathy/default-mode networks. Participant health/ages are not specified in the abstract, so inclusion requires full-text review to confirm at least one healthy adult (17–65) group.

Study uses fMRI with the right pSTS as a social-communication-related target and reports simultaneous rt-fMRI/EEG during a neurofeedback paradigm, which aligns with the review objective. Abstract lacks details on participant health status, ages, and specific task, so inclusion for full-text review is warranted to confirm eligibility.

fMRI study examining guilt-related social cognition (affective and social cognition regions) during imagined and recollected guilt tasks—clearly a social-related task. Abstract lacks explicit participant age/health details; no exclusion criteria met. Include for full-text review to confirm healthy adult sample and extract relevant contrasts.
Non-human subjects: study used three macaque monkeys. Meta-analysis requires fMRI studies with healthy human adults (ages 17–65). Therefore it does not meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study in healthy adult participants (n=21) performing affective theory-of-mind judgments—a social-cognitive task (perception/understanding of others). Not a review/meta-analysis and meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

fMRI study with 20 healthy adult participants receiving empathic vs. unempathic social responses after negative feedback—addresses social cognition/empathy (Perception and Understanding of Others). Fits inclusion criteria (task-based fMRI, healthy adults). Not a review/meta-analysis.

Human fMRI block-design study examining neural responses to perception of facial expressions (social communication / perception of others) in face-selective regions. This meets the review objective of fMRI studies of social processing in likely healthy adult participants; not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to include for full-text data extraction.
The study used fMRI for social joint-attention but participants were children and adolescents; no healthy adult group in the 17–65 range is reported, so it fails the age inclusion criterion.

fMRI study with 37 healthy adult participants performing a social-evaluative task (watching approving/disapproving social videos). Task assesses social perception/understanding; fits review objective of social-related fMRI in healthy adults. Not a review/meta-analysis.

The study used fMRI during a trustworthiness-rating task probing social cognition (perception/understanding of others). Though participant ages/health not explicitly stated in the abstract, it appears to involve healthy adult participants; no exclusion criteria (e.g., review article) apply. Include for full-text review to confirm participant demographics and ages.

fMRI experiment examining person perception and mentalising (social cognition) in human participants; fits social-related task criteria. Not a review. Abstract indicates direct neuroimaging of forming representations of others, meeting inclusion. Participant health/age not specified but typical fMRI study likely healthy adults; include for full-text review.
The study used domestic dogs as participants (non-human), whereas the review requires fMRI studies in human adults (age 17–65). Therefore it does not meet the participant inclusion criteria.

This is an essay/review advocating cross-species social neuroscience, not an original fMRI study. The abstract reports no human participants or fMRI data and fits the exclusion of reviews/meta-analyses.

fMRI study examining theory-of-mind/social processing across social and non-social contexts. Abstract reports neural responses during mental state reasoning and does not indicate a review or clinical-only sample. Participant age/health not specified—include for full-text confirmation.

Functional MRI conducted while healthy adult participants (N=23) performed a visually-based social judgment task (evaluating social dominance in faces), which directly assesses social cognitive processing. The sample consists of healthy adults and the study is empirical (not a review). Fits inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social-related processing.

fMRI study manipulating attention to social meaning vs physical properties of artifacts, reporting activations in social cognition regions (mPFC, TPJ, precuneus, insula). Appears to involve healthy adult participants; meets review objective of social-related processing in fMRI. No exclusion criteria met. Include for full-text review to confirm participant ages/health if needed.

fMRI study of social interaction (virtual ball-toss) in a sample of 38 healthy adult participants examining social reward processing and neural activation. Meets inclusion: task is social-related and uses fMRI in healthy adults (no disorders reported).

Task-state fMRI examining episodic memory retrieval emphasizing self-referential processing (a social-cognitive construct). The study includes control (healthy) participants but ages are not reported and sample focuses on aging/aMCI, so unclear if healthy group is within 17–65. Abstract lacks sufficient info — include for full-text review.

fMRI study with healthy adult participants performing socially-induced cognitive emotion regulation (social cognition/attachment). Task involves a psychotherapist’s social regulation of emotion, addressing affiliation/attachment and social cognition. Not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient detail to meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study of social interaction/retaliation (provocation paradigm) in healthy adult volunteers; examines social-emotional processing (anger/retaliation) relevant to perception/understanding of others. Not a review. Participant group comprises healthy adults (males), fitting age criterion assumption.

Abstract reports neural correlates of mentalizing (a social-cognition construct) and likely neuroimaging, but does not explicitly state an fMRI task was used or provide participant age/health details. Insufficient information to confirm inclusion—include for full-text review.

Abstract describes an fMRI study probing social cognition (empathy, perspective taking, attentional reorienting) using charitable giving and EmpaToM tasks. It clearly fits the review objective of social-related processing in humans. The abstract does not explicitly state participant ages/health status, so full-text review is needed to confirm inclusion criteria (healthy adults 17–65). Given clear use of fMRI and social tasks, include for full-text screening.

Abstract reports resting and unspecified task fMRI but does not indicate social-related tasks. Inclusion requires a social task; abstract lacks this detail, so eligibility cannot be determined from abstract alone. Include for full-text review to confirm whether tasks involved social processing.

Task-based fMRI study assessing empathy and mentalizing in a large sample of healthy adults (N=178). Reports neural analyses (dynamic causal modeling) during social-emotional tasks. Participants are healthy and within the eligible age range; not a review or meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria.

Participants were preadolescents (age 11) rather than adults; the meta-analysis requires healthy participants aged 17–65. Although it is an fMRI social-processing task, the sample age falls outside the inclusion criteria.

fMRI study investigating theory-of-mind/social cognition during cooperative vs competitive interactions with human partners; clearly a social-related task in healthy adults (typical adult sample in NeuroImage paper). Not a review. Meets inclusion criteria.

fMRI was used while participants performed a social cognition task (inferring others’ emotions), directly addressing perception/understanding of others. Abstract does not specify participant ages or explicit health status; insufficient to confirm exclusion. Include for full-text review to verify healthy adult sample (age 17–65) and other details.

Abstract does not report an fMRI study or social-processing task in healthy adults. It examines gene–environment interactions and response inhibition in adolescents (likely including clinical ADHD context), so it does not meet the review’s fMRI/social processing in healthy adult criteria.
Participants are healthy children (mean age 10.2 years). Meta-analysis requires healthy adult participants aged 17–65; thus the study population does not meet the age inclusion criterion.

fMRI study examining neural mechanisms of impression updating/perception of others (social cognition) in human participants; not a review/meta-analysis. Likely uses healthy adult participants and meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI studies.

fMRI study investigating Theory of Mind (social processing) in 19 healthy human participants. Task manipulates mental state inference and contextual adjustments (clearly social cognition). Although exact ages not reported in abstract, participants are described as healthy adults; study fits inclusion criteria for fMRI social processing in healthy adults.

Participants were adolescents (minors). The study sample is described as adolescents with no indication of participants aged 17–65; therefore it does not meet the review’s adult age inclusion criterion.

fMRI study using a social task (Ultimatum Game) assessing cooperative decision-making and neural correlates; appears to be an empirical study with intervention groups. Abstract does not explicitly state participant health status or ages, so include for full-text review to confirm participants are healthy adults (17–65).
Participants are children in middle childhood (roughly ages 7–13), not within the review's required adult age range (17–65). Although it uses fMRI and a social task, the age criterion is not met.

fMRI study in human subjects includes a theory-of-mind (social attribution) task probing social cognition; participants appear to be healthy adults and no exclusion criteria are met. Age range not specified in abstract, so include for full-text verification.

fMRI study using a modified Cyberball task combining social exclusion and performance evaluation, directly investigates social processing and neural correlates. Not a review. Abstract does not report participant ages or clinical status, but likely healthy adults; include for full-text to confirm sample characteristics.

The abstract describes a narrative/review discussion of ecstatic epilepsy and related phenomena using various imaging methods (fMRI, PET, SPECT) and case studies. It does not report an original fMRI experiment in healthy adults performing a social-related task, so it does not meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study with 34 participants investigating neural responses to social interactions during naturalistic movie viewing. Targets social cognition/perception of others (DMPFC), includes healthy participants. Abstract lacks explicit participant ages; include for full-text review to confirm ages (17–65) and health status.

fMRI study of social processing: participants watched actors in angry vs. joyful social situations (perception/understanding of others). Twenty healthy adult participants underwent task-based fMRI. Not a review or meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria.

fMRI study explicitly investigates self-reference versus reference to others—a social cognition task—meeting the review objective. The abstract does not specify participant health status or ages; inclusion is uncertain from abstract alone, so include for full-text review to confirm presence of healthy adults (17–65).

fMRI experiments were conducted with healthy adult participants performing social tasks (Prisoner’s Dilemma, Ultimatum Game), directly assessing social-related processing. Sample sizes and task details are provided and this is an original empirical study (not a review). Meets inclusion criteria.

fMRI study with healthy participants examining attachment-related social cognition (mentalizing) vs control scenes; matches review objective. Age range not specified in abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm participants are adults (17–65).

Abstract reports fMRI findings (perigenual ACC and dorsomedial frontal area 9) during social interactions (cooperation/competition and self-other processing) in human participants. Participant health status and ages are not specified in the abstract; therefore include for full-text review to confirm presence of healthy adults aged 17–65.

fMRI study of social cooperation (one-shot prisoner's dilemma) in healthy adult participants; examines neural responses to mutual cooperation (ventral striatum, OFC). Not a review. Meets inclusion criteria.

fMRI study in healthy adults (N=38) performing mental state judgments (social cognition/mentalizing) using naturalistic social interaction stimuli. Directly addresses perception/understanding of others during fMRI, meets inclusion criteria and is not a review.

Abstract describes a narrative review of adolescent neurobiology, not an original fMRI study. It is a review article (meets exclusion criterion: systematic review/meta-analysis) and focuses on adolescents rather than healthy adults. No primary fMRI methods or eligible adult participants reported.

Abstract reports task-based fMRI of reappraisal of angry faces (socially relevant perception/understanding of others) and functional connectivity related to regulation success, matching the review objective. The abstract does not explicitly state participant health status or ages; therefore include for full-text review to confirm healthy adult sample (17–65). Not a review or meta-analysis.
The fMRI study was conducted in dogs (canine subjects), not human participants. The review requires human healthy adults (age 17–65); therefore the study does not meet the population criterion.

Original fMRI study examining prosocial learning and empathy (social cognition) where participants performed tasks benefiting self vs others. Meets review objective of social-related processing with neuroimaging. Abstract implies human participants in fMRI and is not a review/meta-analysis. Although participant ages/health not explicitly stated, inclusion should proceed to full-text to confirm sample meets 17–65 healthy adult criterion.

Human fMRI study examining mentalizing, empathy, and prosocial behavior (social cognition). Tasks directly assess perception/understanding of others and prosocial responses. No indication participants were clinical; fits healthy adult fMRI inclusion. No exclusion criteria met.

fMRI study with healthy adult participants (25 females) performing a social-cognitive task about kin and friends; addresses social processing constructs (perception/understanding of others, affiliation). Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient detail to meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study using a face emotional processing paradigm addresses social perception/understanding of others. Abstract does not specify participant health status or ages; insufficient information to confirm inclusion criteria, so include for full-text review.

fMRI study examining social competition (a social-related process) with neural measures (mPFC, precuneus/PCC). No exclusion criteria met. Abstract lacks explicit participant age/health details, so include for full-text review to confirm healthy adult sample and age range.

Abstract reports neuroimaging of neural responses to social language and re-transmission—relevant to social processing. However, it does not explicitly state that functional MRI was used nor provide participant age/health details. Insufficient detail to confirm fMRI or sample; include for full-text review.

This article is an explicit review (‘In this review’) of neuroimaging studies, not an original fMRI study reporting task-based data from healthy adult participants. It meets the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses and provides no primary fMRI results for inclusion.

Abstract describes face recognition and neural correlates related to oxytocin receptor variation but does not specify that fMRI was used during a social task. Insufficient information to determine whether study meets fMRI-in-social-task criterion; include for full-text review to confirm imaging modality, task, and participant health/age.

fMRI study of social processing (emotion recognition and eye-gaze integration) in healthy adults; includes a younger healthy group aged 17–27 meeting the 17–65 age criterion. Not a review/meta-analysis.

fMRI study examining neural responses to empathy for pain (a social-related task) and prosocial behavior in human participants. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract does not indicate exclusions (likely healthy sample); include for full-text review to confirm participant ages/health status.

fMRI study with healthy human participants performing social-cognitive tasks (passive observation and explicit emotion judgments of faces), directly addressing perception/understanding of others. Not a review/meta-analysis. Age range not specified in abstract, so full-text should confirm demographics, but abstract provides sufficient basis to include for full-text review.

The study used EEG (mu rhythm) with source localisation, not functional MRI. The review seeks fMRI studies of social processing in healthy adults; modality mismatch excludes this study despite involving social emotion classification.

fMRI study of 40 healthy volunteers performing a social-related task (viewing masked and unmasked facial emotions, including affiliation-relevant emotions). Participants are healthy adults; the task targets social perception/understanding of others. Not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient detail to meet inclusion criteria.

This study is a coordinate-based meta-analysis (activation likelihood estimation; 30 articles). The exclusion criteria explicitly remove systematic reviews or meta-analyses. Although it addresses fMRI social processing in healthy adults, it meets the exclusion criterion and should be excluded.

Non-human primate study (monkeys); fMRI with electrical microstimulation was performed in monkeys, not healthy adult human participants performing social-related tasks, so it fails the human participant inclusion criterion.

This publication is explicitly a systematic review and meta-analyses of fMRI studies rather than an original fMRI study with primary data. It meets the exclusion criterion 'systematic reviews or meta-analyses.'

Functional MRI measured neural responses while participants viewed faces and attended to social aspects (emotional valence), satisfying the social-processing criterion. The abstract does not specify participant ages or health status, so inclusion for full-text review is appropriate to confirm healthy adult sample and age range.

fMRI study with an adult group aged 20–41 performing a social interaction discrimination task (perception/understanding of others). At least one healthy adult group within 17–65 is present; not a review. Abstract provides sufficient info to include.

Non-human animal study using rat pups; resting-state fMRI under anesthesia rather than a task-based social processing paradigm; participants are not healthy human adults (17–65). Does not meet inclusion criteria.

Abstract describes an fMRI social-feedback task relevant to social processing, but participants are described as ‘adolescents’ with no specific ages. Inclusion requires a healthy group aged 17–65; age eligibility cannot be confirmed from the abstract alone. Include for full-text review to determine participant ages and health status.

Abstract reports neural studies of information sharing and social consequences—relevant to social processing—but does not explicitly state use of fMRI or participant ages/health. Include for full-text review to confirm imaging modality and healthy adult sample.

fMRI performed while participants (healthy adults) retrieved biographical/person knowledge about fictitious people—a social cognition task (perception/understanding of others). Not a review. Abstract gives sufficient info to meet inclusion criteria.

Abstract reports an fMRI experiment (n=17) investigating mentalising/theory-of-mind (social cognition) using story tasks in human participants, not a review. Participants are described as human (adult implied); meets social-related fMRI criterion. Recommend full-text for ages and health confirmation, but sufficient to include for review.

Participants are adolescents (not adults within the required 17–65 range) and the fMRI task was a risk-taking task rather than a clearly social-related task. Thus it does not meet the inclusion criterion of fMRI in healthy adults performing a social-related task.

fMRI study in healthy adult participants using an observation/imitation task of emotional faces (social cognitive processing: emotion recognition, social inference). Fits review objective of social-related fMRI in healthy adults; not a review/meta-analysis.

fMRI study of social processing (social exclusion/inclusion, mentalizing) in a sample of healthy male adolescents. Abstract lacks exact participant ages (inclusion requires 17–65), so include for full-text review to confirm age eligibility and health status.

fMRI study of social interaction (making listeners laugh) examining self/other processing and ventral striatum–mPFC connectivity; involves human participants and is not a review. Abstract does not state ages or clinical status explicitly, so include for full-text verification of participant demographics.

fMRI was used while participants considered reading and sharing articles — a social-related task involving self-related processing and perspective-taking (understanding others). Participants appear to be healthy adults; study is empirical (not a review). Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.
Study conducted in macaque monkeys (non-human primates). Inclusion requires fMRI in healthy human participants (age 17–65). Does not meet participant-species criterion, so exclude.

Empirical fMRI study investigating how social information and reward influence decision-making in a group task. The abstract reports fMRI data collected during a social-related task with no mention of clinical populations, matching inclusion criteria for healthy adult social processing. Not a review or meta-analysis.

fMRI study in healthy adult participants (n=19) performing a social task (Trust Game) investigating neural correlates of reciprocity—matches review objective and inclusion criteria; not a review/meta-analysis.

fMRI study in which participants imagined personally familiar others—a social cognition task (perception/understanding of others). Appears to involve healthy adult participants; not a review or meta-analysis. Methods and population meet inclusion criteria.

Original research using fMRI in human participants (N=34) performing a social-emotional task (schadenfreude vs. fremdscham). Examines social cognition, empathy and reward networks in healthy adults; not a review. Fits inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

This is a quantitative review/meta-analysis that synthesizes peak coordinates from prior fMRI studies (no original fMRI data collection). It therefore meets the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses.

fMRI study of social cognition (theory of mind) comparing implicit and explicit belief processing in humans; involves healthy participants and social-related task. Abstract does not report participant ages, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility (age range and participant details). No exclusion criteria met.
Participants are children in middle childhood (ages 8–12), not healthy adults aged 17–65 required by the review. The study therefore does not meet the age criterion for inclusion.

Narrative/review article on resting-state fMRI and social cognition; does not report original task-based fMRI data where participants performed social-related tasks. Does not meet inclusion criterion of task-based fMRI in healthy adults.

Empirical fMRI study of mentalizing/theory-of-mind (social cognition) using two experiments and MVPA in TPJ/STS/MPFC. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract does not state participant ages or health status explicitly, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility (healthy adults 17–65).

Human adult men viewed romantic and sexual stimuli (affiliation/attachment-related task) with reported neural activation differences; no indication participants had disorders. Although the abstract does not explicitly state 'fMRI', the described neural activation during stimulus viewing strongly implies functional neuroimaging. Include for full-text review to confirm imaging modality and participant health status.

Abstract reports a single-case (n=1) fMRI study. Inclusion criteria require at least one group of healthy participants (age 17–65). A single participant does not constitute a group, so study should be excluded.

The fMRI task is a phonological short-term memory (sequence span) task using letters and fingerspelling, focusing on linguistic/visuomotor processing rather than social-related processes (e.g., affiliation, social communication, perception of self/others). Therefore it does not meet the review’s social-processing requirement.

This is a systematic review of fNIRS studies in Autism Spectrum Disorder (children/infants and clinical populations), not an original functional MRI study in healthy adults. It meets the exclusion criterion (review) and does not address fMRI social processing in healthy 17–65 participants.

fMRI was used while participants performed social-related tasks (IAT about adultery and a date-rating task assessing interest in unfamiliar females). Participants appear to be healthy adults in romantic relationships; meets inclusion criteria.

Primary fMRI study in humans examining neural responses (pSTS) to stimuli depicting social interactions, addressing social perception/interaction processing. Appears to involve healthy adult participants and is original research (not a review), meeting inclusion criteria.

fMRI study of 61 healthy adult (White) participants performing a social task (implicit impression formation of Black and White faces varying in socioeconomic status). This assesses perception/understanding of others, fits the review objective, and is not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to include for full-text extraction.

fMRI study where healthy adults viewed a social/moral interaction (kin vs non-kin sisters) — a social cognition task (moral/emotional conflict, mentalizing). Not a review. Age range not specified in abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm participant ages and health status.

Functional MRI experiment with human participants performing a social perception task (judging direction/social intentions of point-light displays and human-like walkers). Directly examines social processing (mirror and mentalizing systems) in healthy adults—meets inclusion criteria.

Study used resting-state fMRI (fALFF) rather than task-based functional MRI during a social-related task. Inclusion requires fMRI conducted while participants performed a social processing task. Although behavioral measures and vignettes assessed social decision-making, the imaging was not task-based, so it does not meet the primary inclusion criterion.

fMRI study where healthy adult participants performed a social-evaluation task (in-group/out-group politician ratings), directly addressing social processing. Abstract does not state exact ages but clearly meets the review objective; include for full-text review to confirm participant ages/health and extract data.

7T fMRI study in healthy adults (fMRI sample n=23 males) using a social/attachment-related task (listening to prototypical attachment narratives) probing social/affiliation and interpersonal processing. Meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults; not a review.

fMRI study with healthy human participants performing retrieval of collaboratively vs. individually learned labels; contrasts involve mentalizing/theory-of-mind and autobiographical memory regions, directly addressing social-related processing (understanding others/social communication). No exclusion criteria met; age not specified in abstract—include for full-text verification.

fMRI study (dynamic causal modeling) of observing cooperative and affective social interactions in 36 healthy adults. The task is social-related (perception/understanding of others), participants are healthy and within age range; not a review/meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI study of social joint action (leader/follower/mutual conditions) involving social cognition, somatosensation, and interaction processes in trained couple dancers (healthy adults). It meets the neurotypical adult criterion and is not a review, so include for full-text review.

fMRI was conducted in healthy adult women (ages 25–50) during viewing of erotic pictures/videos. Although primarily sexual, the task involves perception of other people and the abstract notes activations in areas associated with social cognition, meeting the review’s population and potentially social-related processing criteria. Abstract lacks full task detail, so full-text review is needed to confirm eligibility.

This study used resting-state fMRI in prairie voles (an animal model), not human participants. Inclusion requires fMRI task studies in healthy adults (age 17–65). Therefore it does not meet the population criterion.

fMRI study with human participants performing a social-related task (perception of affective vocalisations/social communication). Abstract shows neural responses relevant to social processing. Age/health details not specified—include for full-text to confirm eligibility.

Abstract does not specify that the movie task specifically targeted social processing nor clearly state adult ages, though TPJ involvement suggests possible social cognition and adults were likely included. Insufficient information to determine inclusion/exclusion from abstract alone — include for full-text review.

The study reports task-based fMRI including social processing (social and emotion tasks) in a large Human Connectome Project sample (n=787). Although ages/health status are not explicitly listed in the abstract, HCP comprises healthy adult participants and the abstract clearly describes social-related task fMRI, meeting the review objective; include for full-text review to confirm ages and participant health status.

fMRI study measuring neural activity during social-cognitive tasks (reflection on self and others) in healthy male adults; directly addresses social processing constructs (self/other perception). Not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

This is a theoretical/chapter-style review of social-interactive neuroscience, not a primary empirical fMRI study. The abstract does not report functional MRI methods or data from healthy adult participants. It therefore meets the exclusion criterion for reviews/meta-analyses and lacks required fMRI task data.

This is a book chapter/review focused on developmental neuroscience and adolescent social influence; it does not report an original fMRI experiment or participant sample (and focuses on adolescents, not adults 17–65). Not a primary fMRI study of healthy adults.

fMRI study examining perception of social interactions (competition vs cooperation) using human point-light figures and moving-shape stimuli, reporting pSTS/TPJ responses. It involves human participants (independent participant group) and is not a review. Age/health details not stated in abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm participant demographics.

Sample consists of children and adolescents aged 8–17; no distinct group of healthy adult participants within the required 17–65 age range is reported, so it does not meet the age inclusion criterion.

This is a narrative/review article about neural mechanisms in primates (including nonhuman primates) rather than an fMRI study of healthy human adults performing a social task; it meets the exclusion criterion for reviews.

fMRI study in healthy adult participants (n=20) using a social decision-making task (modified prisoner’s dilemma) probing Theory of Mind/social cognition (rTPJ activation). Not a review; meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in adults.

Abstract reports an original fMRI experiment comparing social vs. non-social image appraisal (plus an automated meta-analysis). It addresses social processing and is not solely a review. Include for full-text review to confirm participant ages/health status.

fMRI was used while healthy adult participants performed emotion perception tasks (discriminating facial, vocal, and bimodal emotional expressions), which is social communication/perception of others. Not a review and meets age/participant criteria based on abstract.

fMRI was used while healthy adult participants made social decisions influenced by another person; study examines social cognition (perceived distrust/understanding) and neural mechanisms of social control, meeting inclusion criteria.

Functional MRI study probing social communication (prosodic decoding of communicative intentions) with participants performing a social-related task. Abstract does not explicitly report participant ages/health; include for full-text to confirm demographics and eligibility.

Abstract reports task-based fMRI investigating agentic self-evaluation (Perception/Understanding of Self), a social cognitive process. Not a review. Participant age/health not specified in abstract, so insufficient to confirm 17–65 healthy sample—include for full-text review to verify sample and methods.
