fMRI study where healthy adult participants rated perceived intelligence and friendliness of faces—classic social perception/understanding of others task. Fits inclusion (social-related task in healthy adults) and is not a review. Abstract provides sufficient info to include for full-text data extraction.

Single-case report of an 8-year-old with massive bilateral frontal damage; fMRI was used but not to study social-related processing in healthy adults, and there is no group of healthy participants aged 17–65.
Participants were children aged 8–12; the meta-analysis requires healthy adults aged 17–65. Study does not meet age criterion and should be excluded.

fMRI study with 34 healthy adult participants performing an empathic accuracy task (social processing: perception/understanding of others). Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

Participants are adolescent boys (healthy comparison group are adolescents), not adults within the required 17–65 age range. Although it uses fMRI on social self/other processing, the age criterion for inclusion is not met.

Study used resting-state fMRI (RsFc) rather than a task-based social processing paradigm. Inclusion requires fMRI during a social-related task; although healthy controls are included, no social task was performed. Exclude based on not meeting the task-based inclusion criterion.

Participants are preterm infants (31+6 to 36+3 weeks postmenstrual age), not adults, and the task is somatosensory/motor mapping rather than social-related processing. Does not meet participant age or task relevance criteria.

Empirical fMRI data (three studies) examining neural responses to person-related and other social concepts (famous people, social/abstract social words) in the anterior temporal lobes. Appears to involve healthy participants and addresses social-related processing; not a review. Include for full-text review.

The study used task-based fMRI including a 'social cognition' task, which targets social-related processing. It is empirical (not a review) and likely involves healthy adult participants; abstract does not contradict inclusion. Insufficient detail on ages/sample prompts full-text review, so include for further assessment.

Study uses fMRI with a social-reward task in healthy participants and addresses social processing. However participants are adolescents (ages 14–18), so it’s unclear whether there is a subgroup meeting the review’s 17–65 age requirement. Abstract lacks sufficient age-specific detail—include for full-text review to determine eligibility.

Double-blind placebo-controlled fMRI in 55 healthy young men (adult sample) administering intranasal oxytocin while participants viewed attachment-related erotic and fearful social scenes. Task probes social-related processing (affiliation/attachment and perception of others). Not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient detail to meet inclusion criteria.

Abstract reports an event-related fMRI study in which healthy adult participants performed a mind-perception (social) task during scanning, and the work examines brain regions related to social attention. No indication this is a review or that participants were clinical. Meets inclusion criteria for fMRI social processing in healthy adults.

The study used fMRI in non-human primates (macaque monkeys) and includes no human participants. Inclusion requires fMRI in healthy human adults (age 17–65). Not a review/meta-analysis, but fails the human-participant criterion.

This article is a meta-analysis (activation likelihood estimation across 28 fMRI studies). The exclusion criteria disallow systematic reviews or meta-analyses, so it should be excluded despite relevance to social/psychopathy-related processing.

This article is a review (discusses and reviews mechanisms) rather than an original fMRI study. It discusses infants and macaques rather than fMRI in healthy adult humans performing social tasks, meeting the exclusion criterion for reviews and lacking eligible adult participant data.

fMRI study using an emotional face recognition paradigm (social processing: perception/understanding of others). Includes a healthy adult group (mothers without current mental disorders, presumably aged 17–65). Not a review or meta-analysis. Fits inclusion criteria.

fMRI study with 35 healthy adult participants performing a social-related task (recall of self- and other-related relationship episodes). Addresses perception/understanding of self and others; not a review. Abstract gives sufficient info to include for full-text data extraction.

Abstract and title report oxytocin effects on neural activity (anterior insula) in response to positive social stimuli, implying neuroimaging of social processing in humans, but the abstract does not explicitly state fMRI methods or participant age/health details. Insufficient information to rule out inclusion — include for full-text review to confirm fMRI and healthy adult sample.

fMRI study with 16 healthy volunteers viewing social interactions; investigates perception/interpretation of non-verbal and verbal social behavior, matching social-related processing objective. Age range not reported in abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm ages and eligibility.

This is a review article synthesizing task-based EEG/fMRI studies in 22q11.2 deletion syndrome rather than an original fMRI study with primary data in healthy adults. It meets the exclusion criterion (systematic reviews/meta-analyses) and does not clearly report fMRI task data from a healthy 17–65 adult group in the abstract.

This article is a review and meta-analysis of social cognition and PTSD, not an original fMRI study. The exclusion criterion 'systematic reviews or meta-analyses' is clearly met; abstract does not report primary fMRI data from healthy adult participants.

fMRI study examining neural processing of race and socioeconomic status (social perception of others) in a sample of healthy adult participants; not a review or meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

fMRI study investigating integration of facial and vocal emotional expressions—a social perception/communication task (perception/understanding of others). Abstract does not specify participant demographics/ages; relevance to social processing is clear, so include for full-text review to confirm healthy adult sample and age range.

fMRI study of social cognition (learning others' trustworthiness — perception/understanding of others). Involves healthy younger and older adult participants; younger group likely within 17–65 age range, satisfying inclusion. Not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient detail to include for full-text data extraction.

fMRI study examining brain activations during joint leader–follower interactions (social roles) in skilled couple dancers. Involves healthy adult participants performing a social-related task (joint action), fits review objective. Not a review/meta-analysis. Include for full-text to confirm participant ages/details.

The study used resting-state fMRI (rsFC) rather than an fMRI scan conducted while participants performed a social-related task. Although it examines social relationships (peer influence), it does not meet the inclusion requirement of task-based social processing during scanning.

fMRI study measuring neural representations of others' mental states during a social task in male and female human participants. Participants are healthy adults (implied), task assesses social cognition (prediction of mental states). Not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

Study involves children (NVLD, ASD, typically developing children), not healthy adults aged 17–65 required by the review. Also focuses on network connectivity in pediatric clinical groups; does not meet adult healthy participant criterion.

The abstract describes a narrative review of resting-state fMRI findings in ASD and discusses neurofeedback/interaction studies; it does not report original task-based social fMRI in healthy adults. It is a review article and does not meet the inclusion criterion of task-based social processing in healthy participants.

fMRI was conducted while participants performed an iterated Prisoner’s Dilemma (a social decision-making/trust task). Sample consists of healthy adult participants (20 males). Study directly examines social processing and meets inclusion criteria.
Study uses resting-state fMRI (rsfMRI) rather than task-based fMRI; no social-related task was performed during scanning. Inclusion requires fMRI during a social-related task in human participants.
Study used resting-state fMRI (no social task) and participants were adolescents (means ~14.5 years, ranges 10.0–18.0 and 10.0–17.5), not a healthy adult group aged 17–65 as required by the review.

This article is a multi-method review/meta-analytic synthesis (Neurosynth analyses, lesion/TMS/MVPA review) rather than an original fMRI experiment reporting task-based results in healthy adults. It therefore meets the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses.

fMRI study in healthy adults using a dyadic social interaction task (iterated Prisoner’s Dilemma) during scanning; examines neural responses to social interactions under intranasal oxytocin vs placebo. Meets inclusion (social-related task; healthy participants). Not a review.

Abstract reports an fMRI investigation of trustworthiness appraisal (a social-processing task) comparing BPD patients to controls, implying inclusion of a healthy adult control group. Study addresses social cognition and is not a review/meta-analysis. Therefore it meets inclusion criteria for full-text review.

fMRI conducted while healthy adult males (N=93) performed a social provocation/aggression task (Taylor aggression paradigm), probing social cognition and responses to others; meets inclusion criteria and is an original empirical study (not a review).

Task-based dual-fMRI hyperscanning study of social interaction (cooperation vs competition, concurrent vs turn-based), clearly investigating social cognition processes in interacting participants. Uses functional MRI during a social task and is not a review. Participants are described as pairs of individuals (presumably healthy adults), meeting inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

fMRI study of social reward (interpersonal pleasant touch) assessing neural/behavioral responses to social interaction (male vs female experimenter). Includes a healthy adult control group (matched non-using controls). Not a review; meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in adults.

Participants were early adolescents (ages 10.5–13.4), outside the required adult range (17–65), and the study used resting-state fMRI and MR spectroscopy rather than a task-based fMRI of social-related processing.

fMRI was conducted during a social task (face-to-face spontaneous conversation). The study includes an age- and IQ-matched typically developing control group (healthy adults), satisfying the requirement of at least one healthy participant group aged within typical adult range. Not a review/meta-analysis.

The study reports task-based fMRI of theory of mind (a social-cognitive task: perception/understanding of others) in healthy younger and older adult groups. It is empirical (not a review) and includes healthy participants likely within the 17–65 range; include for full-text review to confirm exact ages.

This is an animal study using Fmr1 knockout mice; no human participants aged 17–65 are involved and the task does not assess social processing in healthy adults. Does not meet inclusion criteria for human fMRI social-task studies.

fMRI study using a dynamic facial expression localizer and neurofeedback targeting posterior STS—an area for social perception (face expression recognition). Appears to involve human subjects (no patient group reported) and is not a review. Meets inclusion criteria for social-processing fMRI in healthy adults.

The study used task-free (resting-state) fMRI rather than participants performing a social-related task. Inclusion requires task-based fMRI during social processing; thus it does not meet the primary inclusion criterion despite including healthy controls.

Study used fMRI (hyperscanning) during a live social task—mutual eye contact—which is social processing (perception/understanding of others/self). Participants were healthy adult pairs. Not a review. Meets inclusion criteria based on abstract information.

fMRI was used while healthy adult participants (male and female) viewed faces and performed perceptual similarity and recognition tasks. This addresses social perception/understanding of others (face identity processing), fits participant age range, and is an original empirical fMRI study rather than a review.

fMRI study using live, bidirectional social interaction (human-human vs human-robot), examining neural markers of mentalizing and social motivation. Sample of 21 participants suggests healthy adult subjects. Meets review objective (social processing in fMRI). Age range not specified in abstract, so include for full-text screening to confirm eligibility (17–65).

Study used fMRI while participants observed human and robotic agents experiencing pain/pleasure, addressing empathy and perception/understanding of others—social processing. Participants were healthy adults (n=26). This is an original empirical fMRI study, not a review, meeting inclusion criteria.

fMRI study with healthy adult participants examining co-speech gestures and semantic processing—addresses social communication, a listed relevant construct. Methods and population meet inclusion criteria; not a review or meta-analysis.

Abstract reports an fMRI study of empathy and anxiety during socioemotional processing, which directly fits social-related processing. The abstract does not state participant health status or ages (17–65), so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

The study uses resting-state fMRI (no task) to assess amygdala network causality across the lifespan. Inclusion requires task-based fMRI with social-related processing; resting-state studies without a social task do not meet this criterion.

fMRI study using the Cyberball social-inclusion paradigm (a social-related task) and includes a healthy control group (n=17). Not a review. Age range not reported in abstract, so include for full-text confirmation.

Human fMRI study measuring BOLD responses during a task that manipulated perceived animacy from motion cues. Animacy perception falls under ‘Perception and Understanding of Others’ (social-related processing). Participants are healthy adults; functional MRI was performed. No exclusion criteria met.

The article is a meta-analysis of fMRI studies (systematic synthesis), which meets the exclusion criterion disallowing systematic reviews or meta-analyses. The abstract indicates no new primary participant data, so exclude.
fMRI data were collected at rest (resting-state connectivity); no task-based fMRI during a social-related task is reported. Inclusion requires a social-related task during scanning, so exclude.

Participants are children (ASD and age-matched typically developing children); no healthy adult (age 17–65) group is included. Although it uses fMRI and a social task, it does not meet the adult healthy participant criterion.

fMRI study with healthy human participants undergoing a social-related task (virtual ball-tossing ostracism) examining social support effects on neural activity. Fits review objective (social processing in healthy adults). Not a review/meta-analysis. Age range not specified in abstract, but criterion allows inclusion when information is limited; include for full-text confirmation.

fMRI study of 78 individuals performing a protocol that explicitly includes 'social perception and reasoning' contrasts, directly addressing social-related processing; original data (not a review). Abstract does not report participant ages, so include for full-text review to confirm age range (17–65) and other details.

Functional MRI in a healthy adult sample (n=51) during observation of dynamic facial expressions—a social communication/perception task—fits the review objective. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to include for full-text review.

fMRI study of visual social interactions (dyadic processing) addressing perception/understanding of others in posterior temporal cortex. Abstract indicates human fMRI task relevant to social processing. Participant ages/health not specified in abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm they are healthy adults (17–65).

fMRI experiment examines neural responses to disfigured faces—a social perception/understanding of others task. Abstract implies healthy adult participants but does not state age range or explicitly confirm 'healthy' status; insufficient participant detail for certainty. Include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

Task-based fMRI study of vocal emotional processing (social communication) in 36 healthy participants, directly addressing social-related processing. Not a review or meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria for healthy adult fMRI social task studies; include for full-text review.

This is a narrative review of human neuroimaging literature discussing cerebellar function across domains (including social cognition), not a primary fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults. It meets the exclusion criterion for reviews/meta-analyses and lacks evidence of an original task-based fMRI experiment.

Study used resting-state fMRI before and after rTMS, not a task-based fMRI during a social-related task. Although participants were healthy, the imaging did not assess social processing tasks, so it does not meet inclusion criteria.

The study used resting-state fMRI rather than a task-based social processing paradigm. The meta-analysis requires functional MRI conducted while participants performed a social-related task; although healthy controls were included and social cognition was assessed behaviorally, the imaging was at rest.

Study uses rtfMRI neurofeedback for emotion regulation in healthy adults but does not describe any social-related task or social cognitive constructs (e.g., perception of others, social communication, affiliation). Therefore it does not meet the review’s requirement for an fMRI social-processing task.

The task is a visual color-discrimination/EEG-fMRI study of gamma oscillations, not a social-related task. It does not investigate social processing or social cognition in healthy adults, so it does not meet inclusion criteria.

Study used fMRI during an interactive social (trust) task and includes a healthy control group. However, reported ages are 13–19, so it is unclear whether the healthy participants meet the review’s 17–65 age criterion. Include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

This paper is a meta-analysis/ systematic review of fMRI studies (uses PubMed searches and neurosynth meta-analytic approach) rather than an original fMRI study of healthy adults; exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses is met.

fMRI was conducted while participants (including 15 healthy adult controls) played the prisoners' dilemma—a social cognition/behaviour task—meeting the requirement of fMRI during a social-related task with a healthy adult group. Not a review.

Participants are adolescents (age 16–17) rather than adults. The meta-analysis requires at least one group of healthy participants aged 17–65; this study reports only adolescent samples, so it does not meet the age inclusion criterion.

fMRI study investigating social processing (dynamic facial expressions). Abstract does not clearly state presence of a healthy control group or participant ages; insufficient information to confirm inclusion criteria. Include for full-text review to verify whether healthy adults (age 17–65) were tested.

The study used resting-state fMRI (rsFC) rather than a task-based fMRI during a social-related task. Although it assesses social cognition behaviorally and includes healthy controls, it does not perform fMRI while participants engaged in social processing, so it does not meet the inclusion criterion.

Functional MRI study examining neural representations of honesty during a social task (trustworthiness impressions and subsequent trust interaction) in human participants. Measures social cognition/behavior and predicts trust; not a review. Fits inclusion criteria for fMRI social-processing in healthy adults.

All participants were individuals with alcohol use disorder (no healthy control group); inclusion requires at least one group of healthy participants aged 17–65. The sample therefore does not meet the review's participant criteria.

fMRI study examining perception of others' hand actions (social perception/understanding of others) and includes a healthy participant group (n=31). Age range not reported in abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm participants meet 17–65 criterion and extract details.

Fast fMRI study examines voice processing and explicitly frames findings in social cognition (voice-sensitive auditory cortex), fitting social communication/perception constructs. Abstract does not report participant characteristics or ages (healthy adults 17–65), so inclusion cannot be confirmed from abstract alone — include for full-text review to verify sample criteria.

fMRI MVPA study examining neural representations of affective meaning of social touch; likely included a healthy control group alongside ASD participants. This directly assesses social-related processing. Abstract does not state ages, but inclusion allows studies with at least one healthy group; insufficient age detail means full-text review warranted, so include for screening.
Resting-state fMRI in ASD toddlers; not a task-based social processing fMRI study and participants are not healthy adults (age 17–65). Does not meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI was used while participants recalled World War II displays, engaging medial prefrontal cortex and social-cognitive/collective memory processes. Study involves healthy human participants (adult sample implied) and is not a review. Age range not specified in abstract, so full-text needed to confirm eligibility.
The abstract states this article is a review of the literature on hallucinogens and social processing, not an original fMRI study. Exclusion criterion: systematic reviews or meta-analyses -> exclude.

The study is about screening for autism in young children using questionnaires (M-CHAT-R, BISQ). It does not involve fMRI, social-processing tasks, or healthy adult participants (age 17–65). Therefore it does not meet the inclusion criteria.

Methods paper on probabilistic graphical modeling for multi-view bipartite graph clustering; no fMRI, no human participants, and not about social cognitive tasks. Does not meet inclusion criteria of fMRI social task in healthy adults.
